title: 114_hr4992
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Financial System Protection Act of 2016". Congress found that on November 8, 2011, Iran was identified as a primary money laundering concern, including its Central Bank and private banks. Additionally, on November 6, 2008, the U.S. revoked the "U-turn" license for Iran to protect the financial sector from risks posed by Iran. The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has expressed serious concerns about Iran's failure to address terrorist financing, posing a threat to the international financial system. Businesses operating in Iran face significant risks due to endemic corruption, with Iran ranking poorly on Transparency International's corruption index. Iran's financial sector, including the Central Bank and private banks, poses illicit finance risks globally due to terrorism support and other illicit activities. The US policy is to deny Iran access to US dollar funds through offshore clearing systems overseen by foreign entities. The US policy aims to prevent Iran from accessing US dollar funds through offshore clearing systems overseen by foreign entities for transactions involving the Government of Iran or an Iranian person. SEC. 3. CODIFICATION OF REGULATIONS RELATING TO TRANSFERS OF FUNDS INVOLVING IRAN; CLARIFICATION OF APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS TO FOREIGN DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS AND FOREIGN REGISTERED BROKERS AND DEALERS. Section 560.516 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations, as of January 1, 2016, applies to transfers of funds to or from Iran until the President certifies under the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions Act. Foreign financial institutions are also subject to these regulations. Foreign financial institutions must comply with regulations regarding fund transfers denominated in US dollars, similar to US institutions. The President has the authority to suspend these regulations. The President can suspend regulations for foreign financial institutions or brokers in securities for up to 60 days if Iran complies with specified criteria. The President cannot issue licenses under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act for US institutions to conduct offshore US dollar clearing for Iran. The President cannot issue licenses for US institutions to conduct offshore US dollar clearing for Iran, including processing transfers of funds to or from Iran under specific regulations. Foreign financial institutions or brokers are prohibited from conducting offshore US dollar clearing for Iran or providing US dollars for any offshore clearing system overseen by a foreign entity. Foreign financial institutions are prohibited from transactions involving the Government of Iran or an Iranian person, except for humanitarian purposes on a case-by-case basis. Foreign financial institutions are prohibited from transactions involving Iran, except for humanitarian purposes, which include providing agricultural commodities, food, medicine, or medical devices to Iran, or humanitarian assistance to the people of Iran. The President must submit a copy of the license to the appropriate congressional committees. The terms "foreign financial institution," "Iran," and "Iranian person" are defined in relation to transactions involving Iran. Transfer of funds refers to the movement of funds or property, including transfers for the benefit of an Iranian financial institution between accounts of the same institution. A United States depository institution is defined as per regulations in effect on January 1, 2016. The term "United States registered broker or dealers in securities" is defined in section 560.321 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations, as of January 1, 2016. SEC. 4. Certification requirement for removal of designation of Iran as a jurisdiction of primary money laundering concern. The President cannot revoke a rule designating Iran as a primary money laundering concern without certifying to Congress that Iran has ceased support for terrorism and illicit financial activities. The certification must be unclassified but may include a classified annex. The President must certify to Congress that Iran has stopped supporting terrorism and illicit financial activities to revoke a rule designating Iran as a primary money laundering concern. The certification may include a classified annex. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 14, 2016. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
